I'm not sure why this was played. The situation seems to call for continued development.
I exploit the time-wasting Pawn move by seizing an advantage in development.
Another wasted move. The rule in the opening is ironclad: move your pieces out quickly and only make necessary Pawn moves, or else your middle-game will be inferior.
If White wants to fianchetto the Bishop, 4 P-QN3 and 5 B-N2 accomplish the task a move quicker.
If White wants to fianchetto the Bishop, 4 P-QN3 and 5 B-N2 accomplish the task a move quicker.
Preparing to castle.
Preparing to castle.
I secure my King...
...as does my opponent.
Clearing the last minor piece off the back rank.
Breaking the pin.

My development is complete now, as my Rooks are connected. White still must move his Q off the back rank, so I have a slight advantage in time. Time advantages, however, must be converted before they evaporate.
I see no reason to exchange Bishop for Knight at this stage.
I see no reason to exchange Bishop for Knight at this stage.
Now I'm the one putting the question.
Now I'm the one putting the question.
Maintaining the pin.
I clear my Bishop out of the way and prepare to lock the Q-side with ...P-QN4.
It is not necessary for White to concede the minor exchange here. 13 B-N3 would be acceptable, although I could choose to respond with 13...BxB, doubling the White QNP's.
I complete the exchange.
The Pawn structure on the Q-side is now virtually locked, meaning that the game will proceed at a more sedate pace. Instead of wild attacks, positional maneuvers will be the order of the day.

A mistake, although I miss the fact I can respond 15...QxN.
Apparently White wanted to reposition his Bishop on this diagonal. I'm not sure why, since it allows me to trade off my less mobile KB and preserve my well-positioned, quite mobile QB.
